original_title: Sri Lanka’s EPF makes 47-pct negative return in 2022
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s Employees Provident Fund of private sector workers had made a negative return of 47.24 percent in 2022, based on publicly available data, following record money printing which led to a currency collapse and high inflation.
The EPF’s return on average assets was 9.96 percent according to central bank data against year- end inflation of 57.2 percent in 2022.
Sri Lanka’s inflation soared in 2022 after two years of money printing and a float failed by due to a surrender requirement.
The EPF had also posted a 0.7 percent negative return in 2021, when year-end inflation went up to 12.10 percent, against an average return of 11.40 percent.
Most funds of the EPF are invested in government securities. In stocks there was a market to market loss of 40.9 billion rupees, compared to a gain of 41.8 billion a year ago.
The US dollar value of the EPF also collapsed, compared to the previous year despite new contributions and interest earnings. (Colombo/May08/2023)
